unit_learning_outcomes.description: Deploy knowledge of the principles of archaeological excavation and survey.
Communicate effectively with others regarding strategies for excavation of an archaeological site.
Synthesize and communicate acquired knowledge and understanding to produce a critical analytical report
Demonstrate critical thinking in the interpretation of the archaeological data
Analyse archaeological features and artefacts (e.g., architecture, pottery, stone).

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Read and/or watch assigned material before lectures and practical activities

assessments.description: Quiz will consist of multiple choice or true/false questions that focus on the content of the lectures, textbook, and practicals
Based on the notes you took during classes across the whole session and outside the class.
Using the information provided in class, write a grant proposal (including a budget) convincing a grant review panel that you should receive the requested funds to perform an archaeological project

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances
data.description: This unit examines the methods and techniques used by archaeologists in a variety of field contexts to identify, recover, analyse and interpret their data. In addition to basic archaeological skills, we will also address the key elements involved in designing archaeological field projects, the ways in which theoretical approaches to archaeological work shape the outcomes of fieldwork, and the essential role of disseminating archaeological data to the professional community and the public. The aim is to provide of an active understanding of both basic and more advanced archaeological skills and the development of strategies for the study of sites and the recovery and processing of archaeological data, whether via survey, excavation or post-excavation study.
data.title: Field Methods of Archaeology

description: This unit examines the methods and techniques used by archaeologists in a variety of field contexts to identify, recover, analyse and interpret their data. In addition to basic archaeological skills, we will also address the key elements involved in designing archaeological field projects, the ways in which theoretical approaches to archaeological work shape the outcomes of fieldwork, and the essential role of disseminating archaeological data to the professional community and the public. The aim is to provide of an active understanding of both basic and more advanced archaeological skills and the development of strategies for the study of sites and the recovery and processing of archaeological data, whether via survey, excavation or post-excavation study.
title: Field Methods of Archaeology
